title: How-Tos
content:
Refer to the following examples when configuring a scenario for your integrations.

How to use parse responses and set the output parameters

Each task executes a request against either the current or the target system. Each request has a response. The system captures the response details in the following parameters:

  • response.statusCode: contains the raw HTTP response code of the request.
  • response.data: contains the response body.

To parse the payload received and captured in the response.data parameter, you can use thejson_parser function. Consider the following sample payload from a GET request:

{
    "entities": [
        {
            "entity_type": "Request",
            "properties": {
                "Status": "RequestStatusReady",
                "LastUpdateTime": 1630462073654,
                "Id": "12644",
                "DisplayLabel": "Connection to exchange server is broken."
            },
            "related_properties": {}
        }
    ],
    "meta": {
        "completion_status": "OK",
        "total_count": 0,
        "errorDetailsList": [],
        "errorDetailsMetaList": [],
        "query_time": 1636984213234856
    }
}

To extract the values of the Id and Status from the payload, use the following syntax:

Key Value
Id  json_parser(response.data, '$.entities[0].properties.Id')
Status json_parser(response.data, '$.entities[0].properties.Status')

How to get data from the source and target systems and use the response in the scenario

In some scenarios, you may need additional information from either the current or the target system for further processing. In such cases, you can use the Get Record rule from the Local System or Service Management connector to access information from any entity within Service Management.

For example, if you have a person's ID but need their UPN and Employee Id to uniquely identify and send their information to the target system, you can add a Get Record rule to the scenario.

The following table provides an example for the input and output parameters needed for adding a Get Record rule to the scenario:

Input parameters:

Input field name Value Description
Entity Type 'Person'
Filters 'Id=\''+SourceRequest.Properties.RequestedForPerson +'\'' "SourceRequest.Properties" is an output from another task in your scenario, which contains the information for entity type 'Person'.
Layout 'Id, EmployeeNumber, Name, Upn'  The layout includes the properties to return in the response.
Size 1
Skip 0

Output parameters:

Output field name Value
Object name RequesterDetails
EmployeeId
(key)		 json_parser(response.data, '$.entities[0].properties.EmployeeNumber')
Upn
(key)		 json_parser(response.data, '$.entities[0].properties.Upn')

The output parameters are set after the rule executes. You can then use these values as input for the rules in the payload for subsequent tasks.

What payload do the input parameters in a rule generate?

The following images show a comparison of the input parameters in an Integration Studio rule and the corresponding REST payload in Postman. The example shows a payload for a POST request using the CES API.

How to filter data such as comments for use in the scenario

The following example shows how to filter External Service Desk type comments from the Comment array created within the last 1 minute.

string_agg(filter(json_parser(SourceRequest.Properties.Comments,'$.Comment'),'item.CommentTo=="ExternalServiceDesk" && item.CreateTime>=now()-1*60*1000','{"Comment": to_plain_text(item.CommentBody)}',0),'{item.Comment}','<br>')

The following table describes the sytax in the example.

Expression Description
json_parser(SourceRequest.Properties.Comments,'$.Comment') Gets the comment details from the SourceRequest.Properties output parameter, which is an output of another task. 
'item.CommentTo=="ExternalServiceDesk" && item.CreateTime>=now()-1*60*1000' This is the filter to extract the relevant details from the Comment array. The systems filters for "CommentTo is ExternalServiceDesk" and the "Creation time within the last minute".
{"Comment": to_plain_text(item.CommentBody)}',0), This is the return value of the filter function. The filter DSL returns the Comment body and creates a new Array "Comment" that contains all Comments matching the filter criteria.
'{item.Comment}','<br>' The string_agg function loops through the Comment array returned by the filter function and returns an aggregated string of all elements in the Comment array.

How to get and filter user options and use the result in the scenario

The following example shows how to parse the user option array such as Site_c from the SourceRequest.Properties. The.SourceRequest.Properties is an output of another task and returns the Site_c User Option.

json_parser(SourceRequest.Properties.UserOptions,'$.complexTypeProperties[0].properties.Site_c')

How to configure a retry policy

To retry a task, keep the following points in mind:

  • The retry condition does not support the output parameters of the same task yet.
  • You can use the json_parser function in the retry condition. The response.data (which represents the response body) and response.statusCode parameters are available.

The following table shows an example for setting the condition for a retry policy on the UI:

Input field name value
Condition json_parser(response.data, '$.meta.completion_status')!='OK'
Count
10
Interval (seconds) 5

How to ignore a field mapping

To exclude a property from the final payload, use the ignore_field_mapping() key word. In the following example, the External ID property is excluded from the final payload if the condition does not match. 

Input parameters:

Input field name Value
Entity Type payload.entityType
Id
(Properties > Key)		 payload.entityId
Remote System Parameters.RemoteSystem
Operation 'Update'
External Id ignore_field_mapping()
External Status if(JiraRecord?.Success != undefined && JiraRecord?.Success == 'yes'){JiraRecord.Status} else {ignore_field_mapping()}
External Entity Type ignore_field_mapping()
External URL ignore_field_mapping()
Comment ignore_field_mapping()
Comment Creation Time format(now(),'long')
Comment User Name 'Jira integration'

How to upload attachments from another system to a Service Management record

To upload attachments from an external system to a Service Management record, the following steps are required. The following example shows how to download an attachment from Service Manager and attach it to an Incident in Service Management.

  1. Get the attachment details from an Incident in Service Manager. The following tables provide examples of the input and output parameters needed for adding a Get attachment details from an incident rule to the scenario:

    Input parameters:

    Input field name Value
    Collection name 'XIEIncidents'
    Record Id 'IM10002'
    Output parameters:
    Output field name Value
    Object name Attachments
    type (key) json_parser(response.data,'$.content[0].attachment.type')
    Size (key) json_parser(response.data,'$.content[0].attachment.len')
    SMFileName (key) json_parser(response.data,'$.content[0].attachment.name')
    SMId (key) json_parser(response.data,'$.content[0].attachment.href')

  2. Get the attachment from Service Manager. The attachment Id is referenced in the SMId from the previous task. Remove the cid: prefix and retain only the attachment ID to enable the action to download the attachment. The following tables describe the input and output parameters you must set.

    Input parameters:

    Input field name Value
    Collection name 'XIEIncidents'
    Record id 'IM10002'
    Attachment id replace(Attachments.SMId,'cid:',")
    Output parameters:
    Output field name Value
    Object name XIEAttachment
    tempId (key) json_parser(response.data, '$.uuid')

    The output of this task is the UUID of the downloaded file in the local attachment store from the Integration Studio.

  3. Upload the attachment from the local attachment store of the Integration Studio to Service Management.  In the Form Data section, click Add Property under File parameter, enter the files[] key and add the output value from the previous task which contains the attachment Id of the downloaded attachment. For example:
     

    key value
    files[] XIEAttachment.tempId
    See the following example of the output parameters. You will need them in the next step. 
    Output field name value
    Object name UploadResult
    creator (key) json_parser(response.data, '$.creator')
    contentLength (key) json_parser(response.data, '$.contentLength')
    contentType (key) json_parser(response.data, '$.contentType')
    name (key) json_parser(response.data, '$.name')
    Attachmentld (key) json_parser(response.data, '$.guid')

  4. Update the Incident records attachment settings to add a link between the attachment and incident. Specify following input parameters. Make sure you replace the bold values with the output data from the previous step.

    Parameter Value

    Entity

    'Incident'

    Id

    <your incident Id>

    IncidentAttachments

    '{\"complexTypeProperties\":[{\"properties\":{\"id\":\"' + UploadResult.AttachmentId + '\",\"file_name\":\"' + UploadResult.name + '\",\"file_extension\":\"' + substring(UploadResult.name, length(UploadResult.name)-3) + '\",\"size\":\"' + UploadResult.contentLength + '\",\"mime_type\":\"' + UploadResult.contentType + '\",\"Creator\":\"' + UploadResult.creator+ '\"}}]}'

How to update a user option in a Service Management record

To update the User Option in Service Management, use the following example:

Parameter Value

Entity

<your Entity with UserOptions>

Id

<your record Id>

UserOptions

'{\'complexTypeProperties\':[{\'properties\':{\'Success_c\':\'' + OctaneCreateResponse.Success+ '\'}}]}'

Where the UserOptions parameter value is as follows:

  • Success_c: Represents the Service Management User Option name
  • OctaneCreateResponse.Success: Represents the data to pass to the user option, which can be the output of a previous step in your scenario.

How to reuse parameters in the same rule

Keys and the associated values defined in a Prepare data rule can be reused in the current rule as well as the subsequent rules in the scenario. In the following example, the parameters BaseUrl, Sharedspace and Workspace are used in the Url parameter.

Keys are evaluated from top to bottom. You can reuse a key only if it is already defined.
Parameter Value
Output -> Object name Parameters
BaseUrl 'https://<FQDN>'
Sharedspace 'HR'
Workspace 'ABC'
Url Parameters.BaseUrl+'/ui/entity-navigation?p='+Parameters.Sharedspace+'/'+Parameters.Workspace+'entiyType=work_item&id='

How to run a Microsoft Power Automate flow

To run a Microsoft Power Automate flow, perform the following steps.

  1. Create your flow in Power Automate
    1. In Power Automate, use the When a HTTP request is received connector.
    2. Configure the JSON schema to represent the payload sent from Service Management to Power Automate. For example, create Power Automate flows that add calendar entries in Outlook. To send Subject, Start, and End parameters as JSON payload, use the following schema: 
      {
    "type": "object",
    "properties": {
        "Subject": {
            "type": "string"
        },
        "Start": {
            "type": "string"
        },
        "End": {
            "type": "string"
        }
    }
}
  2. Create an Endpoint in Service Management to connect to Power Automate.
    1. Select No Auth for authentication type.
    2. Enter the Base URL, which is the URL from the HTTP POST URL from the connector in Power Automate.
    3. Copy the server certificate from the server where the power automate flow is running.
    4. (Optional) Add additional headers which are sent with the request. 
    The following sample values for parameters in the General Configuration section.
    Parameter Value
    Endpoint name PowerAutomate
    Agent Agentless
    Authentication Type No Auth
    Protocol https
    Base URL https://<base-url>
    Certificate type X.509
    Certificate format PEM
    Server certificate
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIIPDCCBySgAwIBAgIQB2XGTnTlkdaAOcoqhHVj8DANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFADBw
    MQswCQYDVQQGEwJVUzEVMBMGA1UEChMMRGlnaUNlcnQgSW5jMRkwFwYDVQQLExB3
    ...
    ...
    ...
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----

  3. Create an Integration

    1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
    2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
    3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
    4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
    5. Select Power Automate (under Microsoft) as the connector, select the Power Automate endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
    6. Click Save.
  4. Configure the scenario
    1. Click Add scenario.
    2. Enter a name for the scenario.
    3. Click Save to add the scenario.
    4. Add a Common -> Prepare data rule, followed by a Power Automate -> Run flow rule.

      • In the Prepare data rule, enter the following test data in the Output section.
         

        Parameter value
        Object name Data
        Subject (key) 'My test data'
        EndDate (key) '2022-04-22T12:00:00'
        StartDate (key) '2022-04-22T09:00:00'

      • In the Run flow rule, create the Input JSON payload. See the following sample input for the JSON schema you prepared in the Create your flow in Power Automate step:

        Parameter value
        Subject (Key) Data.Subject
        End  (Key) Data.End
        Start  (Key) Data.Start
  5. To test the scenario, click the Run scenario button.

  2. Create an Integration
    1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.

    6. Click Save. 
  3. Configure the scenario
    1. Click Add scenario.
    2. Enter a name for the scenario.
    3. Click Save to add the scenario.
    4. Add an Operations Orchestrations -> Execute a flow by UUID rule.
    5. In the Execute a flow by UUID rule, fill the required information. See the following sample input values:
    Parameter Description Sample value
    Version / Tenant
    • OO version number for OO Classic
    • OO version / Tenant ID for Operations Orchestration containerized
    • For OO classic: 'v1'
    • Fpr OO Containerized: 'v1/<Tenant ID>'. For example. 'v1/188765331'
    UUID The UUID of the OO flow to run 'd012e1c3-704f-426f-a380-b2425a166d39'

    Log level The log level of the execution. Valid values are STANDARD, EXTENDED. 'STANDARD'
  4. To test the scenario, click the Run scenario button.

How to debug a scenario

The task queue in the endpoints lists all the scenarios and rules that were started during an integration. Within the task queue, you can easily identify the status of a rule in the scenario:

  • Successfully executed
  • Failed
  • Still running
  • Skipped

Every task shows the following details：

  • Request details: Show the request with the final data, including the header and payload that are sent to the target system.
  • Response details: Shows the response to the request from the target system.
  • Output details: Shows the evaluated output result of each rule.

Example:

  • The evaluated Input parameters are captured in the Request details field.
  • The evaluated Output parameters are captured in the Output details field.

How to dynamically specify the shared spaces for the ALM ValueEdge 

This how-to provides an example of how to dynamically set and retrieve the ValueEdge (previously referred to as Octane) shared space and workspace values in Service Management integration with ValueEdge.

There are many ways to dynamically retrieve the values. This example focuses on the method where the ValueEdge Shared space and Workspace information is stored in Actual Services records within Service Management.

Prerequisites 

  • ValueEdge integration is already configured in Integration Studio. 
  • Access to the Service Management administration console. 

Create custom fields

Add the Shared Space and Workspace fields to the Actual Service record to store values used for ValueEdge defects and features.

  1. Navigate to Administration > Studio. 

  2. Select the Actual Service record type. 
  3. Click Custom. 
  4. To add the Workspace field, click New Field and enter the following details: 
    • Name: This is the database field name in the Actual Service record. For example, Workspace. 
    • Multilingual label: This is the display name of the field. For example, Work space. 
    • Logical type: SMALL_TEXT 
  5. Click Save. 
  6. To add the Shared space field, click New Field and enter the following details: 
    • Name: This is the database field name in the Actual Service record. For example, Sharedspace. 
    • Multilingual label: This is the display name of the field. For example, Shared space. 
    • Logical type: SMALL_TEXT. 
  7. Click Save. 

    Add fields to the form 

    Add the Shared Space and Workspace fields to the Actual Service form to allow users to add and edit the field values.

    1. Click the Forms tab. 

    1. Select the Full Actual Service form. 

    1. Click Add Field. 

    1. Select the newly created Shared Space and Workspace fields and click Add. 

    1. Rearrange the fields to the desired position on the form. 

    1. Click Build to apply changes. 

    Populate fields 

     Integration Studio uses these values to set the Shared space and Workspace fields for ValueEdge defects or features.
    1. Open the Actual Service record. 
    2. Enter values for Shared Space and Workspace fields. 

    Set default values

    Set default values for Shared space and Workspace fields. They will be used if the Actual Service record does not have Shared Space or Workspace configured.

    1. Navigate to Integration Studio.
    2. Open the relevant integration flow. For example, Defect Tracking or Enhancement Tracking.
    3. Open the Default Parameters section and enter the default values for Shared space and Workspace.

    Register fields for dynamic retrieval

    1. Go to SMAX -> Get record data
    2. Add the following to the Layout field:
      • RegisteredForActualService.Workspace_c
      • RegisteredForActualService.Sharedspace_c

    Configure the rule to get values dynamically

    Add the rule to the dynamically retrieve the Shared space and Workspace values from the Actual Service record based on the following conditions:

    • If the Shared space and Workspace values are available in the record, retrieve and use it.
    • If the Shared space and Workspace values are not available in the record, use the default value.  

    The following example shows how to add the rule to the Create defect step.

    1. Go to Octane -> Create defect
    2. Enter the following rule in the Shared space input field: 
      if (SMAXRecord.RelatedProperties.RegisteredForActualService.Sharedspace_c != undefined) {SMAXRecord.RelatedProperties.RegisteredForActualService.Sharedspace_c} else {Parameters.Sharedspace}
    3. Enter the following rule in the Workspace input field: 
      if (SMAXRecord.RelatedProperties.RegisteredForActualService.Workspace_c != undefined) {SMAXRecord.RelatedProperties.RegisteredForActualService.Workspace_c} else {Parameters.Workspace}

    Apply these rules in all the steps that require Shared space and Workspace: 

    • For Enhancement, go to  and Octane -> Create Enhancement.
    • For Comment, go to  and Octane -> Create a comment.
    • For record check, go to  and Octane -> Check if record exists.

    Verify Configuration

    1. Test the integration by creating a defect or enhancement in ValueEdge. 
    2. Confirm that the correct Shared space and Workspace values are passed dynamically. 
    3. If no values are set in the service record, the system uses the default parameters defined in the integration. 

    How to leverage the On Premise Bridge for OAUTH2 authentications (client credentials)

    In some cases its required to use the On Premise Bridge to authenticate with a system using OAUTH2 based authentications. As of now, the On Premise Bridge does not support OAUTH2 authentication method natively. However, with the recent enhancements of the Generic Authentication method in the Endpoints it is possible to configure OAUTH2 based authentications, which can go through the On Premise Bridge.

    The option documented here, only supports the OAUTH2 flavor, called "Client Credentials", where a client id and client secret is exchanged to get a token.  "Authorization code"  flavor is not supported when using the On Premise Bridge.
    Please consider following limitations when using On Premise Bridge:
    • Using On Premise Bridge is slower than using a direct connection, hence use it only for integration which are not time sensitive. Do not use it, for example, for the MS teams bot integration.
    • The maximum supported payload size for requests and responses using the On Premise Bridge is 50 KB
    To configure OAUTH2 (client credentials) in an endpoint in Integration Studio, follow the steps in the example below.

    Configure sensitive data in the Endpoint credentials manager in the On Premise Bridge

    Go to the On Premise Bridge and add all secret credential information.

    1. Click New
    2. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as target endpoint type
    3. Click Ok
    4. Select Generic Auth in the Auth type field
    5. Enter a descriptive name for the secret element for example: clientSecret_myApp
    6. Enter the secret information and confirm.
    7. Repeat these steps for any other sensitive information
    Ensure that all characters, except the following, are encoded in the client Id and client secret:
    A–Z a–z 0–9 - _ . ! ~ * ' ( )
    Example:

    Configure the Endpoint in Integration Studio

    The sensitive information is stored in the On-Premise-Bridge.  You can refer to those items in the endpoint.
    Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:
    1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration Studio > Endpoints.
    2. Click Add.
    3. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint, and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
    4. Click Configure and update the fields field values depending on whether the endpoint needs to use the OPB Agent.  
    Field Value
    Agent Select the agent where you configured the sensitive information
    Authentication type

    Select Generic
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL
    Enter the base URL of the system: https://<FQDN>
    For example, to integrate with Microsoft Graph API enter: https://graph.microsoft.com
    Authentication URL

    Enter the authentication URL.This is usuall the URL where the token is generated.

    https://<FQDN>

    For example, to integrate with Microsoft Graph API enter: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<Directory ID (tenant Id)>/oauth2/v2.0/token
    Configure the Authentication request
    Encrypted data
    Parameter: clientSecret
    Value: Select the value configured in the On Premise Bridge credentials manager
    Parameter: clientId
    Value: Select the value configured in the On Premise Bridge credentials manager
    Note: Repeat this step for any other parameter stored in the On Premise Bridge.
    Header
    Add the following headers:
    Key: Content-Type
    Value: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
    Key: Accept
    Value: */*
    Method Select POST
    Body

    Configure the payload for the authentication request as required by the OAUTH2 provider. See the following example, to configure the payload for Microsoft Azure Apps, using the client credentials flavor.

    client_id=${clientId}&scope=https%3A%2F%2Fgraph.microsoft.com%2F.default&client_secret=${clientSecret}&grant_type=client_credentials

    Note:

    • ${clientId} and ${clientSecret} refer to the parameters configured in the Encrypted Data section.
    Ensure that all characters, except the ones below, are encoded in the payload
    A–Z a–z 0–9 - _ . ! ~ * ' ( )

    Extract data from authentication response

    Parameter HTTP Element Key name / JSON Path
    AccessToken

    Body

    		 $.access_token

    Configure headers and cookies for subsequent requests
    Parameter HTTP Element Key name / JSON Path
    (This is a reference to the parameter in the “Extract data from authentication response" section)

    Authorization

    		 Header Bearer ${AccessToken}

    Save the endpoint and use it in the Integration Studio integrations.
